instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are system availability managers in EnergyPlus?
output: System availability managers or AvailabilityManagers are one of the high-level control constructs in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What can an AvailabilityManager do in EnergyPlus?
output: An AvailabilityManager is able to access data from any of the HVAC system nodes and use this data to set flags telling a central air system or plant loop to turn on or off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How do HVACZone components use availability managers?
output: Some of the HVACZone:* components can use these same availability managers to turn their supply air fan on or off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does each type of availability manager encapsulate?
output: Each type of availability manager encapsulates a specific high-level on-off control strategy.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of the input object AvailabilityManager:NightVentilation?
output: The input object AvailabilityManager:NightVentilation allows the user to specify a control strategy for pre-cooling the building with night-time ventilation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Where are availability managers contained in EnergyPlus?
output: Availability managers are contained in the program module SystemAvailabilityManager.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: When are the Availability managers executed in EnergyPlus?
output: The Availability managers are executed at the start of each HVAC time step by a call to ManageSystemAvailability and they reside outside the HVAC system iteration loops.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How often are availability managers executed per HVAC time step?
output: The availability managers are executed once per HVAC time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What do availability managers use to calculate their control actions?
output: Availability managers use previous time step information to calculate their control actions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How is an AvailabilityManager specific to an AirLoopHVAC or PlantLoop referenced in the input?
output: If a given instance of an AvailabilityManager is specific to an AirLoopHVAC or to a PlantLoop then in the input each loop references its availability managers through an AvailabilityManagerAssignmentList.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Where is the AvailabilityManager data for each loop stored?
output: Once the data has been read in and processed the AvailabilityManager data for each loop is stored in array PriAirSysAvailMgr in DataAirLoop (for AirLoopHVAC) and in array PlantAvailMgr in DataPlant for plant loops.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How is the availability status for each AirLoopHVAC passed to a zone equipment availability status array?
output: The availability status for each AirLoopHVAC (PriAirSysAvailMgr) is also passed to a zone equipment availability status array (ZoneEquipAvail) for possible use by the zones served by that air loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the availability status set for certain zone equipment?
output: This sets the availability for certain zone equipment which are assumed to operate in conjunction with the air loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Which zone equipment's availability is the same as the corresponding AirLoopHVAC availability if an AvailabilityManager is specified?
output: Specifically the availability of zone exhaust fans (Ref. Fan:ZoneExhaust) and terminal unit fans (Ref. AirTerminal:SingleDuct:SeriesPIU: Reheat AirTerminal:SingleDuct: ParallelPIU:Reheat and AirTerminal:SingleDuct:VAV: Reheat:VariableSpeedFan) if specified in the input will be the same as the corresponding AirLoopHVAC availability if an AvailabilityManager is specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Which zone equipment are not affected by the AirLoopHVAC system availability managers?
output: Other zone equipment are not affected by the AirLoopHVAC system availability managers (e.g. Window AC PTAC and PTHP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can system availability managers be specified for zone components separately?
output: Yes system availability managers can separately be specified for zone components (currently only allowed for Window AC PTAC PTHP Unit Heater Unit Ventilator Zone Water to Air Heat Pump Zone Terminal Unit (VRF) Standalone Energy Recovery Ventilator Outdoor Air Unit Fan Coil Unit and Ventilated Slab).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How do inputs of zone components refer to their availability managers?
output: Similar to AirLoopHVAC or PlantLoop inputs of these zone components refer to their availability managers through an AvailabilityManagerAssignmentList.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: When do system availability managers operate for zone components?
output: System availability managers only operate when zone components are available.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the Window AC is scheduled off?
output: If the Window AC (or any other unit) is scheduled off then the system availability manager will not operate until the Window AC is scheduled on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How does the functioning of the system availability manager for zone components compare to that for AirLoopHVAC or PlantLoop?
output: The functioning of the system availability manager for zone components is the same as for AirLoopHVAC or PlantLoop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Which SAMs can be specified for zone components?
output: Except night ventilation SAM all other SAMs can be specified for these zone components.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Who takes the actual action of turning on or off a loop?
output: The actual action of turning on or off a loop is taken by the loop prime movers: fans for AirLoopHVACs and pumps for plant loops.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does a fan check to decide whether it is on or off?
output: For instance when a fan is deciding whether it is on or off it checks its on/off schedule and whether the loop availability status flag is CycleOn or ForceOff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the schedule is on and the status flag is ForceOff?
output: If the schedule is on and the status flag is ForceOff the fan will be off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the fan schedule says off and the status flag is CycleOn?
output: If the fan schedule says off and the status flag is CycleOn the fan will be on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What do availability managers overrule?
output: Thus the availability managers overrule the fan on/off schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the input object AvailabilityManager:Scheduled provide?
output: The input object AvailabilityManager:Scheduled provides the simplest availability manager.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the sole input for the AvailabilityManager:Scheduled?
output: The sole input for this manager is a

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What determines the availability of terminal unit fans and Fan:ZoneExhaust in EnergyPlus?
output: Terminal unit fans and Fan:ZoneExhaust will have the same availability as the corresponding AirLoopHVAC if an AvailabilityManager is specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Are other zone equipment affected by the AirLoopHVAC system availability managers?
output: No other zone equipment like Window AC PTAC and PTHP are not affected by the AirLoopHVAC system availability managers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can system availability managers be specified for zone components?
output: Yes system availability managers can be specified for zone components such as Window AC PTAC PTHP Unit Heater Unit Ventilator and others.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How do zone components refer to their availability managers?
output: Zone components refer to their availability managers through an AvailabilityManagerAssignmentList.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: When do system availability managers operate?
output: System availability managers operate only when zone components are available.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if a unit like Window AC is scheduled off?
output: If a unit like Window AC is scheduled off the system availability manager will not operate until the unit is scheduled on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How does the functioning of the system availability manager for zone components compare to AirLoopHVAC or PlantLoop?
output: The functioning is the same as for AirLoopHVAC or PlantLoop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can night ventilation SAM be specified for zone components?
output: No night ventilation SAM cannot be specified for these zone components.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Who takes the actual action of turning on or off a loop?
output: The loop prime movers such as fans for AirLoopHVACs and pumps for plant loops take the actual action of turning on or off a loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does a fan check to decide whether it is on or off?
output: A fan checks its on/off schedule and the loop availability status flag which can be CycleOn or ForceOff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the fan schedule is on and the status flag is ForceOff?
output: The fan will be off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the fan schedule says off and the status flag is CycleOn?
output: The fan will be on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How do availability managers affect the fan on/off schedule?
output: Availability managers overrule the fan on/off schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the simplest availability manager in EnergyPlus?
output: The simplest availability manager is AvailabilityManager:Scheduled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the sole input for the AvailabilityManager:Scheduled?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of AvailabilityManager:NightCycle?
output: It specifies when a system scheduled off during unoccupied hours should cycle on to prevent building temperatures from becoming too hot or too cold.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can AvailabilityManager:NightCycle be used to force a system off?

output: The inputs include a manager applicability schedule the name of the fan schedule this manager will override control type thermostat on/off tolerance cycling run time control type and cycling run time in seconds.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current schedule value is greater than 0.0?
output: The availability status flag is set to 'CycleOn'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current schedule value is not greater than 0.0?
output: The availability status flag is set to 'ForceOff'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOn?
output: It is used specifically to turn equipment on while other availability managers may be used to turn the equipment off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the sole input for the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOn?
output: A schedule name.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the availability status flag set to if the current schedule value is greater than 0.0 for the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOn?
output: CycleOn.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the availability status flag set to if the current schedule value is not greater than 0.0 for the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOn?
output: NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOff?
output: It is used specifically to turn equipment off while other availability managers may be used to turn the equipment on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the sole input for the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOff?
output: A schedule name.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the availability status flag set to if the current schedule value is equal to 0.0 for the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOff?
output: ForceOff.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the availability status flag set to if the current schedule value is not equal to 0.0 for the AvailabilityManager:ScheduledOff?
output: NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of the AvailabilityManager:NightCycle?
output: To specify when a system that has been scheduled off during unoccupied hours should cycle on to prevent building temperatures from becoming too hot or too cold.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can the AvailabilityManager:NightCycle be used to force a system off?
output: No it cannot be used to force a system off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are the inputs for the AvailabilityManager:NightCycle?
output: A manager applicability schedule the name of the fan schedule this manager will override the control type thermostat on/off tolerance cycling run time control type cycling run time in seconds a control zone or zone list name cooling control zone or zone list name heating control zone or zone list name and heating zone fans only control zone or zone list name.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the fan schedule current value is greater than 0 or the applicability schedule value is less than or equal to 0?
output: AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the program is in warmup?
output: The start time and stop time are reset to the current time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the availability status if the current time is greater than the start time and less than the stop time for CyclingRunTimeControlType = FixedRunTime?
output: AvailStatus is set to CycleOn (or CycleOnZoneFansOnly if the control type is Cycle On Any -- Zone Fans only).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What determines the availability status for CyclingRunTimeControlType = Thermostat?
output: The availability status is determined based on the zone air and the thermostat setpoint temperature difference and the tolerance limits.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current time equals the stop time and the CyclingRunTimeControlType is FixedRunTime or ThermostatWithMinimumRunTime?
output: AvailStatus is set to NoAction and the fan schedule will determine if the system is on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current time is greater than the stop time?
output: The manager can potentially cycle the system on for CyclingRunTimeControlType = FixedRunTime Thermostat or ThermostatWithMinimumRunTime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens once the status has become 'Cycle On'?
output: Steps since the start of the current run period are considered once the status has become 'Cycle On'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is required for a control zone?
output: A control zone or zone list name is required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is required for a cooling control zone?
output: A cooling control zone or zone list name is required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is required for a heating control zone?
output: A heating control zone or zone list name is required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is required for a heating zone fans only control zone?
output: A heating zone fans only control zone or zone list name is required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the fan schedule current value is greater than 0 or the applicability schedule value is less than or equal to 0?
output: If the fan schedule current value is greater than 0 or the applicability schedule value is less than or equal to 0 AvailStatus = NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the program is in warmup?
output: If the program is in warmup the start time and stop time are reset to the current time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current time is greater than the start time and less than the stop time?
output: If the current time is greater than the start time and less than the stop time AvailStatus = CycleOn (or CycleOnZoneFansOnly if the control type is Cycle On Any -- Zone Fans only) for CyclingRunTimeControlType = FixedRunTime or CyclingRunTimeControlType = ThermostatWithMinimumRunTime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What determines the availability status for CyclingRunTimeControlType = Thermostat?
output: For CyclingRunTimeControlType = Thermostat the availability status is determined based on the zone air and the thermostat setpoint temperature difference and the tolerance limits.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current time equals the stop time and the CyclingRunTimeControlType is FixedRunTime or ThermostatWithMinimumRunTime?
output: If the current time equals the stop time and the CyclingRunTimeControlType is FixedRunTime or ThermostatWithMinimumRunTime AvailStatus = NoAction and the fan schedule will determine if the system is on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the current time is greater than the stop time?
output: If the current time is greater than the stop time the manager can potentially cycle the system on for CyclingRunTimeControlType = FixedRunTime Thermostat or ThermostatWithMinimumRunTime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for control types CycleOnAny and CycleOnAnyZoneFansOnly?
output: For control types CycleOnAny and CycleOnAnyZoneFansOnly the manager looks at each zone served by the air loop and detects whether the zone temperature at the thermostat is greater than the cooling setpoint plus ½T_tol or less than the heating setpoint minus ½T_tol.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the zone temperature is greater than the cooling setpoint plus ½T_tol or less than the heating setpoint minus ½T_tol?
output: If the zone temperature is greater than the cooling setpoint plus ½T_tol or less than the heating setpoint minus ½T_tol AvailStatus is set to CycleOn (or CycleOnZoneFansOnly). If not AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for control type CycleOnControlZone?
output: For control type CycleOnControlZone the manager performs the same check just for the control zone or zone list.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for control type CycleOnAnyCoolingOrHeatingZone?
output: For control type CycleOnAnyCoolingOrHeatingZone the manager checks the cooling setpoint for the cooling control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn then it checks the heating setpoint for the heating control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if AvailStatus is still NoAction for control type CycleOnAnyCoolingOrHeatingZone?
output: If AvailStatus is still NoAction the manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating zone fans only zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOnZoneFansOnly. If none of these checks are true then AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for control type CycleOnAnyCoolingZone?
output: For control type CycleOnAnyCoolingZone the manager checks the cooling setpoint for the cooling control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn. If none of these checks are true then AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for control type CycleOnAnyHeatingZone?
output: For control type CycleOnAnyHeatingZone the manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn. If AvailStatus is still NoAction then the manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating zone fans only zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOnZoneFansOnly. If none of these checks are true then AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for control type CycleOnAnyHeatingZoneFansOnly?
output: For control type CycleOnAnyHeatingZoneFansOnly the manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating zone fans only zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOnZoneFansOnly.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do when the zone temperature exceeds the cooling setpoint plus ½T_tol or is less than the heating setpoint minus ½T_tol?
output: The manager sets AvailStatus to CycleOn (or CycleOnZoneFansOnly). If not AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What action does the manager take for the control type CycleOnControlZone?
output: The manager performs the same check just for the control zone or zone list.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What actions are taken for the control type CycleOnAnyCoolingOrHeatingZone?
output: The manager checks the cooling setpoint for the cooling control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn then checks the heating setpoint for the heating control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn. If AvailStatus is still NoAction the manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating zone fans only zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOnZoneFansOnly. If none are true AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the manager do for the control type CycleOnAnyCoolingZone?
output: The manager checks the cooling setpoint for the cooling control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn. If none of these checks are true AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the procedure for the control type CycleOnAnyHeatingZone?
output: The manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating control zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOn. If AvailStatus is still NoAction the manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating zone fans only zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOnZoneFansOnly. If none are true AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What action is taken for the control type CycleOnAnyHeatingZoneFansOnly?
output: The manager checks the heating setpoint for the heating zone fans only zone or zone list and sets AvailStatus to CycleOnZoneFansOnly. If none are true AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the new status is CycleOn?
output: The start time is reset to the current time and the stop time is reset.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What control types are allowed when this availability manager is specified for a zone component?
output: The only allowed control types are StayOff and CycleOnControlZone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Night Ventilation -> text
input: What is the purpose of the AvailabilityManager:NightVentilation?
output: It is a manager that looks at indoor and outdoor conditions to see if night ventilation might be beneficial.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Night Ventilation -> text
input: What can the Night Ventilation manager specify besides cycling the air system on?
output: This manager can specify what the ventilation air flow rate should be.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Night Ventilation -> text
input: What inputs are required for the Night Ventilation manager?
output: The inputs are a manager applicability schedule the name of the fan schedule this manager will override a ventilation temperature schedule a ventilation delta T a ventilation low limit temperature the night ventilation flow fraction and the name of the control zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Night Ventilation -> text
input: What happens if the fan schedule current value is greater than 0 or the applicability schedule value is less than or equal to 0 or if the program is in warmup?
output: AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Night Ventilation -> text
input: What are the three limit checks the manager performs?
output: 1) If for all zones connected to the air loop the room temperature at the thermostat of any zone is greater than the ventilation temperature schedule value. 2) If for all zones connected to the air loop the room temperature at the thermostat of any zone is less than the ventilation low limit temperature. 3) If the difference between the control zone room temperature at the thermostat and the outside temperature is greater than the specified night venting delta T.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Night Ventilation -> text
input: What determines the status being set to CycleOn in the Night Ventilation manager?
output: If checks 1 and 3 are true and check 2 is false the status is set to CycleOn; otherwise the status is NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if none of the checks are true?
output: AvailStatus is set to NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What occurs if the new status is CycleOn?
output: The start time is reset to the current time and the stop time is reset.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What control types are allowed for a zone component?
output: The only allowed control types are StayOff and CycleOnControlZone.

input: What is the AvailabilityManager:NightVentilation?

output: A manager applicability schedule the name of the fan schedule this manager will override a ventilation temperature schedule a ventilation delta T a ventilation low limit temperature the night ventilation flow fraction and the name of the control zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the room temperature at the thermostat of any zone is greater than the ventilation temperature schedule value?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

input: What happens if the difference between the control zone room temperature at the thermostat and the outside temperature is greater than the specified night venting delta T?
output: This check is true.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the status if checks 1 and 3 are true and check 2 is false?
output: The status is set to CycleOn.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

output: This manager sets some additional values in the AirLoopControlInfo data structure and in the AirLoopFlow data structure.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

output: It indicates to the fan that it should use alternate performance characteristics if specified in a FanPerformance:NightVentilation object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat?
output: It is a manager that overrides fan or pump schedules depending on the temperature difference between two nodes.

input: What are the inputs for the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for DeltaT in the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat?
output: DeltaT = T_hot node - T_cold node

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What happens if DeltaT is greater than or equal to DeltaT_on?
output: AvailStatus = CycleOn

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What happens if DeltaT is less than or equal to DeltaT_off?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the pseudo code condition for turning off in the AvailabilityManager:HighTemperatureTurnOff?
output: If T_sensed node >= T_u then

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

output: The AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat is a manager that overrides fan or pump schedules depending on the temperature difference between two nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are the typical nodes used for the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat?
output: A typical use would be for one node to be an outdoor air node and the other a zone node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are the inputs for the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Does the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat have an applicability schedule?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What status does the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat return?
output: This manager always returns a status of CycleOn or ForceOff never NoAction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the pseudo code logic for the AvailabilityManager:DifferentialThermostat?
output: DeltaT = T_hot node - T_cold node. If DeltaT >= DeltaT_on then AvailStatus = CycleOn. Else if DeltaT <= DeltaT_off then AvailStatus = ForceOff. Else AvailStatus remains in its previous state. End If.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are the purposes of the AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation?
output: It prevents simultaneous natural ventilation and HVAC system operation and allows users to examine various strategies to maximize natural ventilation to reduce heating/cooling loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How does the AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation work with airflow models?
output: It works with either the AirflowNetwork model or the simple airflow objects to provide controlled natural ventilation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Which objects are referred to as controlled natural ventilation objects?
output: They are AirflowNetwork:Multizone:ComponentDetailedOpening and AirflowNetwork:Multizone:ComponentSimpleOpening objects or ZoneVentilation and ZoneMixing objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can simple airflow objects work with AirflowNetwork objects simultaneously?
output: No they are not allowed to work with the AirflowNetwork objects simultaneously.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can the AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation be applied if there is no air loop?
output: Yes it can still be applied to a controlled zone specified in the object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How should the HVAC air loop name input field be set for zones not served by any air loop?
output: The HVAC air loop name input field must be left blank.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Which zone component objects can use hybrid ventilation managers?
output: They include unit heater unit ventilator packaged terminal air conditioner packaged terminal heat pump zone water source heat pump window air conditioner variable refrigerant flow energy recovery ventilator outdoor air unit fan coil unit and ventilated slab.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens when hybrid ventilation manager is applied to zones served by the ideal load zone component?
output: It can turn them off when natural ventilation is active.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How many hybrid ventilation managers are allowed per zone?
output: It is restricted to one per zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if hybrid ventilation manager is applied to an air loop and a zone served by the air loop also has hybrid ventilation manager?
output: The zone hybrid ventilation manager is disabled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are the two purposes of the availability manager?
output: The availability manager serves two purposes: 1) it prevents simultaneous natural ventilation and HVAC system operation and 2) it allows users to examine various strategies to maximize natural ventilation in order to reduce heating/cooling loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How does the availability manager work with natural ventilation models?
output: This availability manager works with either the AirflowNetwork model or the simple airflow objects to provide controlled natural ventilation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are the controlled natural ventilation objects referred to?
output: The controlled natural ventilation objects referred to here are either AirflowNetwork:Multizone:ComponentDetailedOpening and AirflowNetwork:Multizone:ComponentSimpleOpening objects or ZoneVentilation and ZoneMixing objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Are simple airflow objects allowed to work with AirflowNetwork objects simultaneously?
output: The simple airflow objects are not allowed to work with the AirflowNetwork objects simultaneously.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can the availability manager be applied if there is no air loop?
output: If there is no air loop this availability manager can still be applied to controlled zone specified in the object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How should the HVAC air loop name input field be set to apply the hybrid ventilation manager to a zone not served by any air loop?
output: In order to apply hybrid ventilation manager to the controlled zone not served by any air loop the HVAC air loop name input field must be left blank.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Which zone component objects can use hybrid ventilation managers?
output: Zone component objects such as unit heater unit ventilator packaged terminal air conditioner packaged terminal heat pump zone water source heat pump window air conditioner variable refrigerant flow energy recovery ventilator outdoor air unit fan coil unit and ventilated slab can individually use hybrid ventilation managers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Can hybrid ventilation manager be applied to zones served by the ideal load zone component?
output: Hybrid ventilation manager can be applied to zones served by the ideal load zone component to turn them off when natural ventilation is active.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Is hybrid ventilation manager restricted to one per zone?
output: Currently hybrid ventilation manager is restricted to one per zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How can hybrid ventilation manager be applied?
output: It can either be applied through the air loop or directly to the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if hybrid ventilation manager is applied to an air loop and one of the zones served by the air loop also has hybrid ventilation manager?
output: If hybrid ventilation manager is applied to an air loop and one of the zones served by the air loop also has hybrid ventilation manager then zone hybrid ventilation manager is disabled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How does this availability manager differ from other availability managers?
output: This availability manager performs somewhat differently from the other availability managers: it is called before the program estimates the cooling or heating load for the simulation time step while others are called after the system load prediction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Why is AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation called early?
output: The main reason for calling AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation early is that this manager determines whether natural ventilation is allowed or not and the loads from natural ventilation are used to predict system loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Does this availability manager work with AvailabilityManager:Scheduled?
output: This availability manager has its own control schedule and does not work in tandem with AvailabilityManager:Scheduled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Is AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation dependent on other system availability managers?
output: AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation works completely independent of the other system availability managers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Is AvailabilityManager:HybridVentilation a valid system availability manager type in the AvailabilityManagerAssignmentList object?
output: This manager is not a valid system availability manager type in the AvailabilityManagerAssignmentList object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is described under the 'Control Logic' subsection?
output: The control logic for each ventilation control mode is described below.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the Temperature Control mode check?
output: This control mode checks whether the outdoor air dry-bulb temperature is between the Minimum Outdoor Temperature and Maximum Outdoor Temperature specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the outdoor temperature is between the specified minimum and maximum values?
output: If the outdoor temperature is between the two values then natural ventilation is allowed else natural ventilation is not allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the control do when natural ventilation is allowed?
output: When natural ventilation is allowed the control checks the temperature difference between the zone temperature and the temperature setpoint(s) in the controlled zone based on the specified temperature control type to make a final decision.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of overriding the decision in the Single Heating Setpoint control type?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

output: If the zone temperature is beyond the deadband the initial decision is overridden and natural ventilation is not allowed. This is intended to avoid either overcooling a space which could result in additional heating load when the zone temperature is below the heating setpoint or overheating a space which could result in additional cooling load when the zone temperature is above the cooling setpoint.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What must be done with the relative humidity setpoint for comparison?
output: The value of relative humidity has to be converted into the setpoint of humidity ratio using the actual zone air temperature for comparison.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the actual zone air humidity ratio is below the humidity ratio setpoint?
output: If the actual zone air humidity ratio is below the humidity ratio setpoint and the controlled zone needs humidification then the initial decision is overridden and natural ventilation is not allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the intention of overriding the initial decision when the zone needs dehumidification?
output: This is intended to avoid humidifying a space which could result in additional dehumidification load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the zone temperature is beyond the deadband?
output: If the zone temperature is beyond the deadband the initial decision is overridden and natural ventilation is not allowed to avoid overcooling or overheating a space.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dew-Point Control -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Dew-Point Control -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Operative Temperature Control with 80 Percent Acceptability Limits -> text

input: What happens if the zone air operative temperature is within the 90% acceptability limits?
output: If the zone air operative temperature is within the 90% acceptability limits natural ventilation is allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: CO2 Control -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: CO2 Control -> text
input: What happens if the zone air CO2 concentration level is above the setpoint?
output: If the zone air CO2 concentration level is above the setpoint the control checks the availability of the HVAC system. If available the status will be ForceOn; if not natural ventilation will be allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Outdoor Ventilation Air Control -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Availability Status -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Availability Status -> text
input: What is the availability status if natural ventilation is allowed?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Optimum Start Controls -> text
input: What is another term for optimum start?
output: Optimum start is often also referred to as optimum recovery time.
