input: What does the operative temperature control with 80% acceptability limits check?
output: This control mode checks whether the zone air operative temperature is between the lower and upper adaptive comfort 80% acceptability limits or not.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the zone air operative temperature is between the lower and upper limits in the 80% acceptability control mode?
output: If the zone air operative temperature is between the lower and upper limits then natural ventilation is allowed else natural ventilation is not allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the operative temperature control with 90% acceptability limits check?
output: This control mode checks whether the zone air operative temperature is between the lower and upper adaptive comfort 90% acceptability limits or not.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the zone air operative temperature is between the lower and upper limits in the 90% acceptability control mode?
output: If the zone air operative temperature is between the lower and upper limits then natural ventilation is allowed else natural ventilation is not allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the CO2 control mode check?
output: This control mode checks whether the zone air CO2 concentration level is above the CO2 setpoint or not.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the zone air CO2 concentration level is above the setpoint in CO2 control mode?
output: If the zone air CO2 concentration level is above the setpoint the control checks availability of HVAC system. If available the available status will be ForceOn. If not available natural ventilation will be allowed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the outdoor ventilation air control mode require?
output: This control mode does not require any additional checks.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What objects does the outdoor ventilation air control work with?
output: The control only works with Airflow Network opening objects only and is not allowed to work with ZoneVentilation and ZoneMixing objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens after the hybrid ventilation control determines whether natural ventilation is allowed or not?
output: After the hybrid ventilation control determines whether natural ventilation is allowed or not the availability status flag is set as follows: If Natural Ventilation then AvailStatus = CycleOn Else AvailStatus = ForceOn End If.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is optimum start often referred to as?
output: Optimum start is often also referred to as optimum recovery time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How are commercial buildings often operated intermittently?
output: Commercial buildings are often operated intermittently by lowering heating set-point and increasing cooling set-point during unoccupied period.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Why is it important to start the operation of heating and cooling plant before building is occupied?
output: The building should return to set-point just before occupancy period starts. Therefore it is important to start the operation of heating and cooling plant before building is occupied.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the operation is started too early or too late?
output: If the operation is started too early before the occupants return energy is wasted. If it is started too late the occupants will be uncomfortable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the benefit of an optimum start time for operation?
output: An optimum start time for operation will save energy without compromising comfort.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 301 depict?
output: Figure 301 depicts Optimal Start Control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the ASHRAE Handbook refer to regarding optimum start control?
output: ASHRAE Handbook refers to work done by (Seem Armstrong & Hancock 1989) which compares seven different equations and suggests a set of equations for preheating and precooling time prediction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are some algorithms used for predicting the start time for the HVAC system?
output: There are a few algorithms to predict the start time for the HVAC system. Among these algorithms following are the promising ones that can be implemented in a simulation environment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the constant start time algorithm?
output: This is the simplest format of the optimum start algorithm. The HVAC system will start the HVAC system at a fixed number of hours before occupancy as specified by the user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the constant temperature gradient method used for?
output: In practice most of the HVAC control manufacturers use a temperature gradient as a thermal capacity factor in which temperature rise per unit time i.e. °C/hour is measured for the unoccupied building and then the difference between space temperature and set-point temperature is divided by this factor to calculate the actual number of hours before occupancy are needed to start the HVAC system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the importance of starting the operation of heating and cooling plant before building occupancy?
output: The building should return to set-point just before the occupancy period starts so it is important to start the operation of heating and cooling plant before building is occupied.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What happens if the operation of heating and cooling plant is started too early or too late?
output: If the operation is started too early before the occupants return energy is wasted. If it is started too late the occupants will be uncomfortable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the benefit of an optimum start time for operation?
output: An optimum start time for operation will save energy without compromising comfort.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is depicted in the figure labeled 'Optimal Start Control'?
output: The figure labeled 'Optimal Start Control' is depicted in media/image6731.png.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the ASHRAE Handbook refer to regarding preheating and precooling time prediction?
output: The ASHRAE Handbook refers to work done by (Seem Armstrong & Hancock 1989) which compares seven different equations and suggests a set of equations for preheating and precooling time prediction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What are some promising algorithms for predicting start time for HVAC systems?
output: Among the algorithms the promising ones that can be implemented in a simulation environment are Constant Start Time Constant Temperature Gradient Adaptive Temperature Gradient and Adaptive ASHRAE Algorithm.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the simplest format of the optimum start algorithm?
output: The simplest format of the optimum start algorithm is the Constant Start Time where the HVAC system will start at a fixed number of hours before occupancy as specified by the user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How do most HVAC control manufacturers use a temperature gradient?
output: Most HVAC control manufacturers use a temperature gradient as a thermal capacity factor where temperature rise per unit time (°C/hour) is measured for the unoccupied building and the difference between space temperature and set-point temperature is divided by this factor to calculate the actual number of hours before occupancy needed to start the HVAC system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What does the adaptive temperature gradient algorithm do?
output: The adaptive temperature gradient algorithm modifies the temperature gradient depending on the time required to meet the set-point on prior days using the arithmetic average of the actual temperature gradients calculated for the specified number of previous days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What method is used in the Adaptive ASHRAE Algorithm to determine optimum start/recovery time?
output: The Adaptive ASHRAE Algorithm uses equations suggested in the ASHRAE Handbook in combination with a recursive linear least square method to determine the optimum start/recovery time empirically.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for precooling time?
output: The equation for precooling time is: \(t_i = a_0 + a_1 T_zi + a_2 T_zi^2\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for preheating time?
output: The equation for preheating time is: \(t_i = a_0 + (1 - w_i)(a_1 T_zi + a_2 T_zi^2) + w_i a_3 T_oi\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What factors influence the weighting factor \(w_i\) in the preheating time equation?
output: The weighting factor \(w_i\) is determined by the difference between zone temperature \(T_zi\) and unoccupied setpoint temperature \(T_unocc\) and the difference between occupied setpoint temperature \(T_occ\) and unoccupied setpoint temperature \(T_unocc\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for the weighting factor \(w_i\)?
output: The equation for the weighting factor \(w_i\) is: \(w_i = 1000^- \frac(T_zi - T_unocc)(T_occ - T_unocc)\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How are coefficients \(a_0\) \(a_1\) \(a_2\) and \(a_3\) determined?
output: Coefficients \(a_0\) \(a_1\) \(a_2\) and \(a_3\) are separately calculated for heating and cooling operation and are updated from the optimum times from the last three days thus carrying history and adapting the trend from previous days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the purpose of adaptive control in modifying the temperature gradient?
output: Adaptive control is used to modify the temperature gradient depending on the time required to meet the set-point on the prior days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How does the adaptive algorithm determine the temperature gradients?
output: The adaptive algorithm takes the arithmetic average of the actual temperature gradients calculated for the specified number of previous days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What method is used in conjunction with the ASHRAE Handbook equations?
output: A recursive linear least square method is used in conjunction with the ASHRAE Handbook equations to determine the optimum start/recovery time empirically.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How is the start time categorized depending on the operation?
output: Depending on heating or cooling operation the start time is categorized as preheating or precooling time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What is the relationship between preheating time and outdoor temperature?
output: The preheating time is a strong function of outdoor temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: Does precooling time have a strong relationship with outdoor temperature?
output: Precooling time is not a strong function of outdoor temperature if space temperature is close or less than the setback temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How many different equations are suggested for preheating and precooling time?
output: Two different equations are suggested for preheating and precooling time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for precooling time?
output: t_i = a_0 + a_1T_zi + a_2T_zi^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for preheating time?
output: t_i = a_0 + \\left( 1 - w_i \\right)(a_1T_zi + a_2T_zi^2) + w_ia_3T_oi

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What do the variables in the preheating and precooling equations represent?
output: On the i-th day: t_i is the start/recovery time T_zi is the zone temperature T_oi is the outdoor temperature w_i is a weighting factor which determines weighting given to outside and zone temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for the weighting factor w_i?
output: w_i = 1000^ - \\frac\\left( T_zi - T_unocc \\right)\\left( T_occ - T_unocc \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What do T_unocc and T_occ represent?
output: T_unocc and T_occ are setpoint temperatures during unoccupied (setback) and occupied periods respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: How are the coefficients a_0 a_1 a_2 and a_3 calculated and updated?
output: Coefficients a_0 a_1 a_2 (and a_3) are separately calculated for heating and cooling operation and are updated from the optimum times from the last three days; these coefficients carry history and adapt the trend from previous days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> equation
input: What is the equation for determining the optimum time for past days?
output: t_opt\\left( i - 1 \\right) = k_\\left( i - 1 \\right)\\Delta t - \\Delta t\\left( 1 - \\fracq_\\left( i - 1 \\right)q_max \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: System Availability Managers -> text
input: What do the variables in the optimum time equation represent?
output: k are the time steps required for recovery \\Delta t is the time-step t_opt(i-1) is the recovery time on (i-1)-th day q_(i-1) is the energy extracted or added during the last time step q_max is the maximum capacity of the equipment.
